It seemed like all the servers were happy to wait on us as they walked by, never did we have to wait for anything. 

Very nice interior, casual, not cramped. The food was pretty good. Wasn't my top sushi in the city but still very good. The udon was really nice as well as everything else we tried. I am gonna go back for sure!!
author: Tracey E.

description: Went to Tenichi a couple times. First experience was good, food came out on time and tasted good also. But the other few experiences had terrible service. Had some questions on the menu and our waiter had no clue! He actually took the menu and read the ingredients to me. Like I couldn't do that myself, hahah! So I ordered a summer breeze roll and what our waiter gave to us was a few pieces of nigiri. Then Stormed off! Overall decent food, annoying and unpleasant service! The management should do a better job on hiring there staff.
author: Ed V.

description:
I'd really give this place four and a half stars if I could.

There are three types of sushi places in my mind: Great, Bad and Solid. The solid ones are almost the toughest ones to find because you expect a certain level of consistent fish and that can be really tough with sushi in my experience.

You've got to give props to any family owned restaurant that has been around for years and years. Moreover these people are just really nice. Any one of the reviews below that talk about bad service miss the point: These waiters are really nice people. If the service is bad, it's generally because they are slammed or just a little flustered--and that is "bad" service I can live with.

Their rolls are very good. Not insanely inventive like Blowfish or Tsunami but still really nice.

And as for people who say there are other places in the neighborhood to go, I don't know what they are talking about. Ten Ichi blows away any other place on Fillmore except maybe Yoshi's.

Kirin on tap too!
author: Paul C.

description: Standard fare Japanese food that is okay to eat, but for the price it is not worth coming here unless you absolutely must have sushi and are in the area. (couldn't find anything else walkable) had the crunchy roll... Rice was solid, spicy tuna was sparse, size was small, although the texture was good. Cooked foods was not anything special. Katsudon meat quality was standard... Nearly juicy or dry. The fried outside was neither soggy nor particularly crispy. I'm not sure why they put mushrooms in it either. All in all, it was okay Japanese food, but too expensive for what you get.
author: Lars B.

description:
My short and sweet review: 

Came here for lunch. Sushi was not fresh, over-priced, poorly rolled and the service was SLOW! This sushi looks like the kind that I make myself. 

For three rolls and (lukewarm) edamame, wait time was 1 hour + on a Wednesday! 

Prices weren't cheap either, which would have negated some of the slow service.

THE SCOOP: This place is not worth it! Better alternatives await!
author: Tom A.

description:
3.5-4 Stars

The service was friendly and attentive.  

The food was pretty good, I recommend the halibut gyoza (very delicious), shrimp tempura (tasty, not overly fried and battered), the sushi "taco" - I forget what they were called but they were on the separate menu and definitely would go back for these.  

I left satisfied, but as with others thought it was a little overpriced.  However the proximity, friendliness, and taste would definitely bring me back.
author: Vivek G.

description:
It was great a couple years back.
I used to enjoy the Sukiyaki there.
Had decent service.

The reason why I'm giving it a three star is,
the service downgraded.

 the food isn't the most authentic, but kinda good in its own way.
and the greetings,... they lack the zeal, the energy, and aren't very attentive.

They're more like zombies walking around now.
author: Cadence C.

description: Very disappointed with Ten-Ichi. I saw several decent reviews and figured I'd give it a try since it is right down the street from my apartment. I give it a second star only because the wait staff was very friendly when i arrived to pick up my order. Let me begin. The sushi rolls themselves were tiny, and they had very little fish in them. So little that I was shocked when I opened my bag. The calamari was dry, tasted like it was made the day before, and comes with no sauce. Finally, they charged me for an extra roll that I did not order, but I wasn't about to walk back down the hill to ask about it. Overall, I don't recommend. There must be better options around here.
author: Jon T.

description:
Families galore.  If you are looking for a place to bring your kids, this could be your joint.

I went at 7pm on a Friday and found the place half full, half of that was families with wiggley yelping kids.  This is fine, but know that going in.

If you like a little bit more of a "religious" sushi experience, no way.

The food disappointed me. Cheap white round plate ... nigiri combo thingy.  Fish was fairly hack job. California roll (oh, oops, did that come with this?) Was sloppy. Cheap soy sace in a la choy looking dispenser. 3 out of the 8 or so nigiri didn't seem fresh. God help you if you get sashimi here.

All the stars are for the cute friendly servers.
author: Michael E.

description:
Very fresh sashimi and a wide variety of cooked appetizers and entrees. Prices are as to be expected for good fish.

Also, the staff is very friendly. I recommend sitting at the bar and having the sushi chef make recommendations. I tried new fish I've never had before, and found some new favorites.

By the way, this place has been owned by the same husband & wife for 35 years. Support local business!
author: jason e.

description: The owner's son has sent me not one, but two nasty "compliments" in response to my first posting - the most recent one came yesterday, 14mos after my review!  A little sensitive are we?  I guess people aren't allowed to their opinions.  I wonder if his sweet Japanese parents, who have owned Ten-Ichi for decades, know that he's being such a jerk to their customers.  Any thoughts of giving it another try are now long gone.  Way to go, son.
author: Ellen H.

description:
Get the mushroom soup.  Get the mushroom soup.  Get the mushroom soup.

The fish is outstanding.

Service rocks.

And, we get to watch Monday Night football on the big screen if we sit at the right table.
author: Jessie S.

description:
walked in, ordered food, and literally sat for 30 min.  I wanted to pick up dinner and just go home since I had a long day at work and what I got was 30 min of waiting with the outcome being very unfulfilling.

sat there for 30 min without anyone asking me that they are checking on my order, no offer of a glass of water or tea...

when i finally got my food, i walked home and when I opened the box, i saw this tiny portion of beef...and alot of tempura, i thought I was getting beef with a side of tempura.  the beef was overcooked and rather thin slices which isnt the way i normally like my beef teris

the place obviously has been in the area and part of the same ownership for too long...the owners are probably pretty complacent, which shows in the lack of service and the average food.

sorry...will not be visiting this place again!
author: Rin c.

description: Oh my God what a disaster of a place! We walked in at 6:50. How do I know? We missed happy hour by 20 mins. No biggie. 20 mins later we placed our order. 25 mins after that, we got.....one seaweed salad....of which we ordered two. If you're keeping time, that's 45 minutes. I confronted the owner. She confronted the waiter. He confronted the sushi chef. He threw up his hands. Nobody threw themselves on the sword. Nobody did anything to preserve their honor. So much for Japanese culture. Long live the great American tradition of passing the buck.  We left, went home and watched The Last Samurai.
author: Travis H.

description:
Unclean.  Overpriced.  Mediocre.  

I ate here tonight for the 2nd time.  I wanted to like it.  I'm looking for a more upscale sushi place with good food, and this place is in my neighborhood.  The first time was okay.  Tonight, I actually left the restaurant surprised at how unnecessarily bad my experience was.  

First of all, I found dirt and stone about the size of my fingernail in my spinach salad.  2nd, the rolls are mediocre.  The rolls are made with thinly cut fish so that the fish is difficult to taste.  The nigiri was good, though.  Not amazing, but good.  3rd, the prices are high.  For example, $15 for a Rainbow roll.  The prices on their website are not updated.

Finally, I did not find the place to be friendly. 

You can do better in San Francisco.  In nearby Japantown, a few blocks away, you can get the same quality for a cheaper price with a friendlier attitude.  I see no reason to come here.
author: Mutant J.

description:
The BF and I were going for a walk around the neighborhood and suddenly he had a craving for a philly roll just as we were passing by Ten-Ichi. We stopped in and ordered a philly roll for him and a california hand roll for me to go. We didnt bring our wallets with us, considering we were just going for a walk, but luckily he had $16.00 in his pocket and we thought that would be enough. Boy were we wrong...

The total came out to be $16.43-- we were $0.43 short!! How embarrassing but the owner was so sweet and told us that it was OK and to have a great evening even after we told her that we'd go home to get extra money to bring back to her. Whew!

The sushi was fresh and they used the real stuff, no imitation, which probably explained why the total came out to be $16.43. Kind of pricey for such small portions but I guess its Pac Heights - everything is overpriced!
author: M W.

description:
I'm almost offended by some of the so-so reviews given here. Ten-Ichi is a fantastic family owned Sushi restaurant. They've been in business on Fillmore for over 30 years. That has to say something about the place. I'll tell you what else says something about this place....their Toro. Its almost like dessert its so delicious.

My recommendation: 

1 order of toro nigiri, 1 order of hon-maguro nigiri, 1 order of hamachi and the American Dream roll. Simple and perfect....you won't be disappointed. Also, sit at the sushi bar and engage with Steve and the other sushi chefs. Its hard not to love this place when you watch their seafood magic in action. 

I've eaten a lot of sushi in San Francisco and I just don't really waste my time going anywhere but here anymore.
author: Kimberly B.

description: We wanted something reasonable and gave Ten-Ichi a try. The special menu seems a little weird for a traditional Japanese restaurant, but if you stick to the standard fare such as tempura and sushi, it's fine. Not going to win any awards - I mean, it's not Kiss Seafood Restaurant - but it's good enough for a neighborhood restaurant. We will definitely add it to the rotation!
author: Karen C.

description: I could go on and on about the long waits and poor service, but at the end of the day: the portions are tiny, expensive, and forgettable. If I wanted to pay for location, there are more enjoyable places on Fillmore.
author: L N.

description:
Ten-Ichi is like homecooking to me


 ...if my family were Japaneseand my mom made sushiand she charged me for itand she lived in Pacific Heights


 Somaybe it's not like homecooking.


 But it is CONSISTENTLY among the best sushi I've had in San Francisco. A lot of places go up and down. Ten-Ichi doesn't waver. I go there at least once a month, alone, sit at the sushi bar and prepare to have the most satisfying meal of sushi I can ask for. It's more or less home for me.


 But the price. They know they're goodand they charge for it. I would go once a week, if it were more affordable. But as a single, lonely, loser who works for a video game company and spends a lot of time alone, by himself, playing video games aloneI can only afford to go once a month since I spend upwards of $25-$30 aloneby myselfwith no one elseeverfor eternity.


 Oh Ten-Ichiwhy dost thou forsake me?!


 Try Ten-Ichi out. Make it that place you go to alone to treat yourself, or with a friend for a nice night of sushi and a film at the Clay Theatre.


 Hold me.
author: dunedonkey

description:
Recommended this restaurant to so many people.  We came in last Saturday, it's been a while, service was so slow, food was o.k., don't like the small plate menu... 

Steve, just read your comment that the restaurant is going through major changes... maybe time to reconsider some of those?
author: On C.

description: I agree with many of the other Yelpers here who point out that the sushi is fair and the portions are relatively small (e.g., rolls with only 4 pieces). Generally, this  would be ok but the prices are quite high for what you get. The service is outstanding- staff is friendly and attentive.
author: Jonathan S.

description: I used to come here in high school, and it's still great. Fresh, big portions of sushi, perfect miso, and crispy light tempura.  I definitely think this is one of the better places on Fillmore.  It's a little bit more than the places in the Mission, but definitely worth it.  Reminds me of the 90s in a good way.
author: Julia D.

description: Overpriced, small portions, and sloooooow service.  Many better options in SF
author: SF Y.

description: First off, I ate here over 9 years ago and it was wonderful.  Last night, not so much.  The CA roll must have been a left over or made the night before.  It was soggy and disgusting.   The gyoza was even worse....cold and VERY porky tasting, again probably left over.  The teriyaki beef over rice was very good though.  I would not step foot again in this restaurant.  And we paid $100 for dinner which left me feeling robbed.
author: Joshua E.

description:
I wouldn't call myself a sushi snob, but definitely a finicky fish eater. My best friend loves this place, but if it were my pick I'd usually opt for south of California street for Sushi. However, on this occasion my friend treated me, and woohoo I loves me some free sushi, so hello! Ten-Ichi!

And I was pleasantly surprised.

I love it when Sushi chefs fess up about what's freshest. The hamachi was rich, mouth-filling bliss. The california rolls were fresh and delicate because of the real crab and lack of mayonnaise. As well, we had some other, how to put it gently, jive-ass rolls, that overall were pretty good. $70 for two felt a little high, but the service was great, I was full, happy, and had a great time catching up with my friend.

3.5 * stars
author: Brady K.

description: Horrible! Service was extremely slow! Even the check took over 10 minutes. The sushi was not put together nicely, quality of the fish mediocre. Do not recommend will not come back!
author: Val G.

description: Hopped in here for lunch yesterday.  Very good food, but service a bit slow if you are in a hurry.  Also, a bit more pricey than what we are used to.
author: Donna R.

description: I use to live down the street many years ago and did not take advantage but my sister and her family go there a lot.  I just love when Japanese own Japanese restaurants!  What I like about it it is off the beaten path for tourists but if you are a tourist you should try it!  A cab ride is worth it!  The family still runs the restaurant and you can feel it when you sit.  Try the daily menu but I went with the combination white meat chicken and crispy fish.  OK this is home cooking so that is why they get the 5 stars.  the best thing is I ordered the brown rice and it was like Seki-han, man that was the best rice!  (rice and beans).  You must try it!!!
author: Toby N.

description: Been here twice now and the sushi was very mediocre both times. Priced as if it were better though.
author: Drew L.

description:
Just wanted a quick Japanese fix and something super close to my apt. Should have taken the time to head to Japan-town or elsewhere but we ended up at Ten-Ichi. This place tends to have a decent amount of people in it and it's super reasonable. 

our edammame was over cooked and consequently a bit mushy. My veggie plate was average, but that's about it. Nothing special, just not great. Large menu with nigiri, sashimi, sushi, udon, donburi and specials. The decor was blah. Service was efficient.
author: Theresa T.

description: Adding Ten-Ichi to my Fillmore St. lunch list. ~$10 for a Bento Box special. You'll get rice, a few pieces of tempura, California Roll, and a protein like Chicken/Steak teriyaki or Chicken katsu. Friendly service and quick turnaround if you're pressed for time. Solid choice.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
Okay, from the reviews, I'm getting that Ten-Ichi is *not* the place you want to go to for a teriyaki-bento-box-type dinner. HOWEVER, I've been here about 5 or 6 times and have always sat at the sushi bar as I like to see what I'm eating and how it's prepared. I order a couple of things off the regular menu and a couple of specials every time I go and have *never* been disappointed by the quality and cut of the fish. Quality as in consistency, taste and freshness. 

F'rinstance...
Toro - melts in your mouth
Home-made smoked salmon - outstanding
Sea trout - I had to order another one
Spanish mackerel - perfect balance of flavor

AND, to top it all off, it is officially Mumsy Approved. Took her there last weekend and she said it was "as good or better than ______" (my previous #1 sushi joint) and she loved that they didn't use lots of rice - just the right proportion to fish. 

The service is efficient but not too brisk, friendly but not obsequious, and the sushi chefs are all wonderful. AND they have natto (for those of you who don't know what it is, don't order it!!!).

And, to top if off, she left her little tote bag there and they kindly kept it all nicely wrapped for me to pick up the next day.)

Yup, this is officially my favorite sushi place....
author: Mi M.

description:
Do you think real sushi eater come to place like here?
It's a right in the rich upper Fillmore neighborhood.
The location helps this Japanese Restaurant.
A lot.
One of the oldest Japanese restaurant in town.
But also the location changed this restaurant menu for their rich customers.

Their customers know everything about their Japanese food.
But in Japan,
you have to pick up a bowl of rice and eat w/ chopsticks.
You can not leave the bowl of rice on the table and eat the rice w/ fork.
Pick up the bowl, please.
Same as a bowl of miso soup.
Pick it up, dumb ass!

Everything in this place is small portions and pricey.
Very  pricey!
Small and expensive for the customers who just wants to have a chit chat with friends from the rich, high class neighborhood.
They don't care about the food.
This owner knows that. 
Smart!
Knows his market very well.

It's just an another snobbish mediocre Japanese restaurant.
This place is clean, safe, nice, healthy and has well mannered waitresses.
But the food is so-so, not bad, not good.
To me...
Nah.
Why don't you waste money.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I don't like sushi.  

Oh, don't give me that look.  I'm not alone --- I even belong to an I-won't-eat-raw-fish-in-San-Francisco-and-that-makes-me-a-social-pariah support group.  

I do, however, like udon.  No, I loooovvveee udon!  Chicken udon full of fresh vegetables and those wonderful noodles is just about the best food on earth.  I try to have it at every Japanese restaurant possible.

So when friends wanted to try Ten Ichi the other night I agreed to go, knowing I would be able to try yet another restaurant's version of a favorite comfort food.  We were seated immediately in this tiny, narrow place, and provided with menus.  Ordering took a while as the waitresses seemed to magically forget our table existed, even while bringing dishes to the tables to either side of ours.  Disinterested service irritates me, so I was not exactly thrilled with Ten Ichi --- until they set down my HUGE bowl.  

Oh. My.  This was the king of udon --- full of perfectly cooked vegetables, tender chicken, tasty noodles and a lovely broth.  After that I had to struggle with my feelings.  Any place with food that good deserves a second chance on the whole service thing.  Besides, I would almost be willing to sell my soul for that udon.
author: Suzanne B.

description:
Call me a snob, but you'd think that for a sushi joint on Fillmore street, you're almost gauranteed for a higher calibre dining experience.  Well, apparently when you assume things.... you run the risk of being proven wrong.

I'm sorry, but I was just so unimpressed with this place the other night.  The menu wasn't that original, the service was painfully slow and the rolls were freakin' miniature!

I don't see myself returning here, for there are far better sushi options in this city that I'd rather spend my money on.
author: Katie C.

description: Been coming here for the past three years and it's become our favorite sushi spot. They've improved their menu and added some amazing rolls over the years. The speciality rolls are completely worth it. Our favorites are No Name and Temptation. Highly recommend.
author: Allison F.

description:
My friend and I were on our way to see a special screening of the Science of Sleep at the Clay Theatre, so decided to stop into Ten-Ichi for some quick sushi.

It was relatively quiet, but the customers all seems like regulars. We sat at the bar, and the friendly sushi chef soon had us enjoying some very fresh sushi rolls and a few pieces of sashimi as well. 

For a neighborhood sushi spot, or as a healthy respite from a gluttoness day of shopping on Fillmore, Ten-Ichi is a solid option.
author: Nish N.

description: My sister lives up the street from Ten-Ichi so whenever I'm around the area we always try to fulfill our sushi craving here. We usually get hooked up with gyoza and other goodies for my sister is always a regular, so my experience here is usually good. Not only is it in a good location, so is the atmosphere. I can rant on and on about Ten-Ichi but you really just have to go there to experience it.
author: Mirabella C.

description:
This place is the only sushi joint in the city that has my favorite appetizer.  Forgive my blatant whiteness, but I can't recall the name... but its so so so yummy.  It's super thin strips of beef wrapped around green onions, and then pan fried or somehow cooked.  *gets chills*

Anyway.  The rest of the sushi that I've had here is also quite good, but nothing to get chills over.  And it is more expensive than most places.
author: Hilary K.

description:
STAR for fresh fish!
STAR for daily specials!
STAR for unique variations on rolls!
STAR for friendly staff!

Minus STAR for higher priced than some other places.

EQUALS: 4 STAR!
author: Dazza M.

description:
Usually, I don't consider Zagat ratings to be dispositive.  However, in this case, i think they got it right.  This place "earns" its 19 rating.  

The beef sukiyaki was neither hot nor tasty.  The soup was mostly watered down soy sauce.  The chicken katsu donburi was soggy - it felt like I was eating mush.  On top of that, the service was slow and inattentive.  

If you want Japanese food, do yourself a favor and go somewhere else.  No real lover of Japanese food could go here and not regret it.
author: Matt P.

description:
The quality of the fish here is second-to-none. They even had ankimo, which is a long time favorite of mine but seldom on the menu.

I highly recommend just going with some sashimi and nigiri from the daily specials menu -- can't go wrong there. The aji was some of the best I've never had in my life, and the ankimo was on-par with ANY sushi joint in SF or even New York hands-down. 

The staff was courteous, fun, and friendly but I do agree with some fellow Yelpers reviews that they could be a bit more expedient. Less time having fun, more time serving the amazing sushi the chefs are cranking out. Don't go here if you're very much in a hurry.

If you want amazing quality sushi in a fun, friendly, neighborhood place -- Ten-Ichi is a sure bet!

Campai!
author: Matthew J M.

description:
Had some really great sushi here. The standouts were the aji and uni, which in my mind are sort of the yardstick for any sushi place.  

Seriously, the uni, fresh from the waters of Mendocino, was so good that I insisted on ordering another so I could have it as my finale.  The last bite is always to be considered, but takes on an even greater importance during sushi.
author: L W.

description:
Ten-Ichi has really great food.  I love their Tempura!  Last night i have to say it wasn't that crunchy and delicious,  It was Soggy.  
They are super nice their and the service is OK. If the Tempura is crunchy like normal I would say it is ONE OF the best in the city!
author: Adrian L.

description: Pretty average. Nothing special. Menu seemed overly super sized ie too many options. Would suggest they pair down the menu and focus on slightly higher quality. I would eat here again if I really needed a sushi fix.
author: Janelle C.

description:
I went to Ten-Ichi with a group of 6.  Most of the specialty rolls were 4 pieces to a roll for $10+.  We felt it was too expensive for what we got. Especially when you have Godzilla sushi right around the corner on Divisadero and Bush... why would you ever waste $10+ for a 4 piece specialty roll?  At least they drizzled some sauce around the plate for that cheesy artistic look.

I tried to send my specialty eel roll back because the grilled eel (listed as the first ingredient) was nowhere to be found.  The waitress and sushi chef laughed at me and said I had to eat it and that they had made it correctly.  My friend ordered a tuna cut roll, and the rolls were soooo small.  One even had a small pinch of fish in it, and she tried to send it back saying that she paid for sushi, not seaweed wrapped rice... and the waitress also refused to take it back.

We had a good appetizer of 3 different types of seaweed salad.  Best part of the meal was the Andes mints afterwards.  We went home to have 4th meal since this place sucked.  Not recommended. Walk a few blocks to Godzilla sushi... you will love it.
author: Ian F.

description:
So far, the best sushi I have had in the city.  Granted I still haven't been to a ton of places... but this one is still fantastic.

The Ken's special is delicious.  Three fresh handrolls (California, Unagi and Tuna and Scallions) for just $9, hard to beat.

The tempura is perfect.  Some places don't get the veggies right, but this place makes them brilliantly.

The quality of the fish they use is so much better than other sushi restaurants.  If you are in Lower Pacific Heights, and you need sushi... forget the wait at Godzilla and just go to Ten-Ichi.  You will thank me.
author: Adam O.

description:
It's nothing spectacular but it is affordable sushi in Pacific Heights. The rolls and sashimi tasted nice and fresh at least it just wasn't on par with some of the amazing sushi I've had elsewhere in the city. Come on, the ocean is right there, you should be getting some sublime pieces in the mix no?
It is nice and affordable though especially compared to some of the swankier places on Fillmore in that area.
author: Cathy T.

description:
Update 3/3/08
So, I didn't give up. Their Beef Udon is tasty, nice mushroomy broth. The Seafood Udon was also quite tasty, tons of seafood, mild broth, could've used a bit more kick. Yummy Gyoza.


Have been here a few times now. I've gotten the bento box twice, don't really love the way they do it. Had 2 app's the other day.  The pork goyza were good. I also got fried tofu w/ a garlic chili sauce. It was so nasty. I was expecting fried tofu, maybe it saw the fryer. The sauce was a gelatinous goop. I was hungry, so I scraped it off and ate the not fried tofu.  Will never get that again.  Might try other things though.
author: C B.

description: I tend to have a very hit or miss experience with sushi, so I was actually pleasantly surprised by the "No Name Roll," which was very good, but at the end of the meal I wasn't happy to have paid $70 for an ordinary weeknight dinner.  Given the number of sushi restaurants in the area, this place didn't stand out enough to make me want to make an effort to go back.  The atmosphere was fine, the service was fine, and the food was mostly pretty good, but the prices are not commensurate with such a casual, simple place.  I agree with another Yelp reviewer who said the items are about $2-3 too much -- that's exactly right.  That said, if you love mango, avocado, tuna and eel, then go here just to try the No Name Roll.
author: Molly P.

description:
whoa. this place kinda hurt my feelings. the sushi was mediocre and SMALL. six little pieces for a $14 dragon roll. wha? that's just mean. after $80 for two people, we should've left full. i was hungry again two hours later, and i'm really not a big eater.

i'm not one to care AT ALL about decor/ambiance either, but at these prices it shouldn't look like you're in a 1990's sizzler. there should be monkeys in top hats doing the can-can. please.

their aprons were pretty cool though.
author: Grace C.

description: This is our favorite sushi restaurant in SF! The sushi is fantastic and we suggest sitting at the Sushi Bar and letting Steve make you something off the top of his head.
author: BRIAN B.

description:
I have been going here for 20 yrs. Always good service, especially at the sushi bar. A MUST TRY: cold noodle salad. My personal fav. 
Great sashimi, good sake selection, great traditional Japanese food. I love it. It is on the spendy side.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Been here for sushi a few times.  Granted, there's nothing wrong with the sushi here; it's always fresh and tasty... but that's about where the fun ends.  The service is sometimes painfully slow to the point where you wonder if they've forgotten about you.  The rolls are really small, smaller than average.

I just don't think I'm going to bother with Ten-Ichi anymore.
author: Sarah R.

description: Best sushi in town!  Family owned and very comfortable environment.  I usually sit at the bar where the waiter makes up rolls that he thinks I will enjoy.  The fish is ALWAYS fresh and sooo delicious.  Try the American Dream, it's my favorite!
author: Lisa A.

description: This a cute little sushi place with really nice decorations. The sushi is really good, but expensive. My favorite rolls are the caterpillar and crunch roll. The chicken teriyaki dinner plate is just okay. The asian chicken salad is good but small dishes are over priced. The waiter service could be better.
author: Luis C.

description:
Ten-Ichi provided a wonderful and unique sushi menu because they create flavors beyond typical such as jalapeño, asparagus, seared meats and sauces. 
Their wait staff is very attentive albeit a little quiet. Ask questions about the menu and beverage list and you won't miss a good recommendation.
author: Matthew G.

description: Our new neighborhood favorite... I'm suprised by the not-so-great reviews.  I highly recommend sitting at the bar and letting Steve tell you what's good that night.  Take in the fun, family owned atmosphere.  The Ultimate.  The American Dream.  The Firecracker... oh and the new menu has some great non-sushi plates too!
author: Alison W.

description:
Haven't been back to Ten-Ichi for a long time because the last experience was AWFUL.   Tonight was a repeat of the same AWFULNESS.

The very pink salmon that came couldn't possibly have any more color additive.   It wasn't even fresh - the pink flesh was falling apart.   

The fatty toro didn't even taste like fish.  Good fish shouldn't smell like  sewage. 

The hamachi.  Horrible.  

The only good thing about this place is the friendly service - but good service doesn't really matter when the food SUCKED.  

As with many things in life, sometimes you just need to recognize that it's an awful experience and move on.   No more.
author: Shirley F.

description:
This is my go to place (in the neighborhood) for fresh, consistently delicious sushi with NO wait EVER and casual atmosphere...large resturuant (unlike some of my fav. sushi joints which are the size of my closet)..
Its got everything on the menu: sushi, sashimi, rolls, teriyaki stuff, udon stuff and some others too..Something for everyone.
The service is great:)
Sushi is good, always..medium sized pieces of nigiri and sashimi and traditional rolls as well as some specials 
one of my favorites: Inside out albacore tuna roll with avocado, cucumber inside..
author: CadoBaby P.

description:
I'm honestly surprised that this place isn't always packed. Maybe it lacks a catchy name? In any case, it's some of the best sushi in the City. Ken, the head sushi chef, creates both wonderful cut fish and really interesting delicious rolls. His hamachi is better than any I've tasted -- he must have a connection! The specials are truly special, not just something to clean out the fridge. Ken's magic sauce is yummy -- try anything covered in it.

I recommend sitting at the bar if there's only a couple of you. You'll get to talk to Ken and Johnny, watch the sushi be made, and get slightly better/faster service. (Don't get me wrong, the table service is great but at times a bit slow.) Also, try the sake sampler. Delicious!
author: Sean M.

description:
While the food here is average, not terrible, its the service that really gets me.  You will have to continously have to wave down the servers for tea.  And one one occassion, the server accidently spilled tea on me, and didn't even apologize.  

I think I'm pretty reasonable, but when its not busy, and no one else is in the dining room, you can afford to spend time on the table that you do have.  Am I right?  Needless to say, I did not tip.
author: Cass J.

description:
Sushi was okay, I believe over priced, service SUCKED. Would go back again, was maybe short staffed and revise my review but at this time
Meh, I've experiened better
author: Kenn P.

description:
I really wish place was better than it really is. I mean for a restaurant to be open for as long as it is I would think that it would be so much better. 

I do not think the sushi is neither great nor the rest of the food. And to top it off it is really expensive for what you get. I mean the service is below average. I live 3 blocks from this place and have lived in this area for over 5 years so I have been here a few times due to convenience sake but I also wish it could be better and I am always disgusted with my bill when I leave. 

You are better off going to Sushi Rock on polk and sacramento. It is cheaper and you can print out a 20% off coupon online. Plus, they have validated parking across the street.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
This is my favorite sushi place in SF.  

Why?

1) Location.  Its direclty across the street from my house.  

2) Johnny.  

3) Rolls.  Its all about the Indian Summer Roll, the Crunchy Roll and the Nuclear Roll.  

4) Tuna Carpaccio.  Heavan.

5) MELLOW.  Killa doesnt like a rowdy croud on a Thursday night or want to dress up.  Just want to get my sushi at the bar, eat and HEAR who I am eating with.   SERENITY NOW!

6) Andes mints
author: Killa r.

description:
So we're sitting in Ten-Ichi talking about an incident where Alexis, the resident alcoholic, was left alone with another friend affectionately referred to as "the russian."  This is bad because (a) Alexis was passed out from too much Jagr and (b) "the russian" is slightly shady.  Someone in the group then says, very loudly, at the exact moment that the entire restaurant randomly went completely silent, "I don't think the russian would molest me, but he'd defintely molest you!"  All eyes turn.  We burst out laughing.  Good times.

So did we have a good time?  You're damn skippy.  Is this place the reason?  Ehhh.  Average sashimi, slow service, not much of  a sake list, ambiance nothing to write home about.  Just average all the way around.
author: Jason S.

description:
So, the service wasn't great...but the food alone will bring me back. The indian summer roll (tempura green beans on the inside, eel and avocado on the outside) is clearly their most popular roll for a reason...delicious blend of textures and tastes. My entree, the spicy green bean and chicken saute was total Asian comfort food. I would have liked it more if it hadn't been served in a huge bowl.

My mango sake-rita was also fabulous! Blended perfectly with hints of mint.
author: lindsay w.

description:
This sushi spot is just ok. The place is kind of eerie, and doesn't really get upbeat. I've walked past it during happy hour and there are significantly more people eating/drinking. None of the actual sushi is discounted during happy hour, just bento boxes and what not (teriyaki chicken dinners, etc.)

Service was good, and you could tell it was family owned. Overall the sushi quality was good but the portions for rolls are extremely small. Rolls are either 4 or 8 pieces, being the smallest I've seen at a sushi restaurant. I wouldn't mind if it wasn't overpriced, but I paid $10 for a roll that only had 4 pieces. They weren't small, but I can go to Umami (down the street) and pay $13-15 for the same size pieces, just getting 8 instead of 4. All in all, I probably will never go back since there are plenty of sushi spots in SF.
author: Nick C.

description:
Food is forgettable - service regrettable.

10 better restaurants within eyeball range.  Pass.
author: Clay C.

description:
Delcious, fresh sushi.  The halibut (I think that is the fish they used) potstickers were sooooo good.  They are pan fried instead of deep fried, which was totally yum.  Light, scrumptious, and addicting.  The gommae was light and the sesame dressing on the spinach didn't overpower the spinach.  I had my usual, the California roll.  Then I shared one of the special rolls with my sister.  It has tempura jalapeno, some kind of fish (sorry I can't remember), and other yummy ingredients.  

The chefs are so nice there.  The presentation is lovely.  Our server was efficient and nice.  Since my sister had met the owner before, we got free shochu and mochi for dessert.  Yay.  

The menu is pretty large, and full of wonderful rolls, dishes, appetizers, etc.  There were so many things I wanted to try!
author: Sarah F.

description:
My roomies and I went here for dinner Saturday night. This was my second time at this place. Strangely enough, there was a regular who was there the last time I went. The chef has a great personality and apparently makes the best sake bombs, or so I'm told. I stuck to my beer, fish, and gohan. 

Like many sushi restaurants in the Bay Area, the chef is Korean. With that said, the sushi didn't have that kim-pap feeling to it and was actually pretty decent all things considered. Either that or my taste in sushi is getting Americanized. I'll go with the chef tries hard and is pretty good compared to many of the rest. 

I'd go back but not often.
author: Kevo M.

description:
I have to admit that I'm a little bit confused by the lunch menu at Ten-Ichi.  Unless you order a sashimi combo, there are no rolls or sashimi on the menu.  I ended up with the teriyaki/sashimi combo, which was very good, but came with salmon sashimi and had no other fishy options.  I think I would have been happier with more variety (or a yummy roll).  

The food was excellent, so I'll be back, but I think I'll stick with their dinner menu.
author: Katie S.

description: I have only been here for lunch, nonetheless the sushi here was baaaad! We had pretty standard rolls, including the crunch, salmon and super white and none of them were very good. The quality of fish used was not the freshest.  The service was awful. I try to cut the waiters slack when it is rush hour for lunch or dinner, but this particular visit was just absurdly bad. It took them FOREVER to do everything, from bring a glass of water to the check.  There are so many other places in the neighborhood to get a quick roll and I suggest you do so.
author: Nichole P.

description:
I came here for dinner on a Friday night to find it surprisingly not full.  The service was amazing, and our server was extremely helpful in picking out what to get.  I definitely recommend asking the server about your dish before ordering as she'll give you some helpful hints.  

We ordered a variety of dishes and shared.  The sushi and sashimi were fresh; the special appetizers were unique and delicious as well.  The only complaint I had was how small each dish was and how expensive our bill came out to be.  I don't expect fresh sushi to be cheap, but the amount of food was just way too small and that'll likely keep me from coming back despite the great service.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I love this place. 

The sushi is exceptional and the atmosphere is perfect for a date or group of friends.

Do your self a favor and always ask the sushi chefs what's fresh for the night and you will never be disappointed. Steve always makes great off the menu creations. 

They have great chicken karrage... sashimi carpacchio and tall the special rolls are hands down amazing.
author: Mark B.

description:
We went here at the height of the Saturday night dinner crowd with no reservation. They were very quick to seat us although the service was a bit abrupt. 

The fish was fresh and delicious. Also, they had non-fish items, which is crucial for every sushi place that I go to with my husband since he doesn't eat fish. 

Everything was good, but a bit on the pricey side for food that is just 'good'.
author: lindsey l.

description: A little expensive, but thats what you get with sushi on Fillmore.  The owner is super cool, we sat down at the sushi bar, and he basically made us custom rolls based on what we liked.  Also gave us free mochi balls!  I love ordering "off the menu", it makes me feel special.  High quality fish, great service, definitely going back.
author: Ryan H.

description:
Ok with their improvment in service....I decided to give them one more star.  The food here is great and now its even better with the improvement in service.  It doesn't take forever to get your order now.  I was able to sit down, order, get my food and eat within 40 minutes and that includes the time to walk there and back.  

My favorite dishes there is the ginger beef...its so damn yummy.  I've also had the garlic chicken don...also very good.  My friend had the gingered veggies and added chicken to it....a very healthy alternative to my beloved gingered beef dish.  The next time I come back I do need to try the tofu salad.  Saw the chick next to me eating it and it looked hella good.  Glad I can put this place back into my rotation.
author: Allison T.

description: Came here for an early dinner at 5:30p. Was here with a couple of friends and their family. Food was quick, but ok.  What disappointed me was their service. Right from the beginning, they were rushing us. Even when at 5:30p, there were a lot of open tables.  They gave us the check even when we weren't done. Then when we were done, they were quick to hurry us out. Keep in mind we had young children (2 yr olds) in our group and a baby. Knowing that, the restaurant should understand we would take a while to eat and get ready to leave. The kids were well behaved. I don't appreciate being rushed out!
author: Linda Y.

description:
When we moved from San Francisco in 2002, Ten Ichi, although not the BEST sushi in town, was always a solid, fancy choice.  Good rolls, decor that seemed to be a little formal yet trendy.  A solid package for entertaining, really.

Five years later... we move back and give it a try...

And five years later, this is not the case.  I don't know what happened, but the line that used to extend out the door on a weekday night was conspicuously absent on a Friday night.  We were seated immediately, which should have been our first tip off.  

Once we could finally get served and get drinks - here's an idea - have the wait staff actually know what's on the drink menu, we ordered.  

We ordered edamame.  What we got was very cold edamame.  

We ordered a sake sampler, which was nice, but I was thirsty, and getting another round was impossible.  And, as I said, the place was not crowded.

We ordered a selection of nigiri sushi and a few rolls.  Except for the baby amberjack, which was special, the sushi was tasteless.  The rolls were also bland.

The icing on the rice cake was the bill - which was large, especially given the lack of service and the lack of quality.  It's cool that my new cell phone has a built in tip calculator so I could quickly compute a 12.5% tip, and we joined the long line at the door - waiting to get out.
author: Pete G.

description:
Very expensive. The Steak Teriyaki was good and the Sushi was fresh for a Tuesday, however, the nigiri cut was quite small and expensive. $40 for two pair of nigiri, 2 beers and a boll of rice with steak teriyaki. 

Ambiance was pleasant and the place was clean. Service was responsive and professional.
author: James C.

description: I've only been here once, when my cousin treated me out for lunch.  Yet, I quite liked the food and service.  The ambiance of the place is great!  I've always been a fan of Japanese food!
author: Myka S.

description:
This is a review about eating dinner there on Nov 2, 2008.

Fast, attentive service.
Sushi was fresh and well crafted.
Plenty of green tea refills without having to ask.

Minus - and this is not a direct reflection about the restaurant.  Rather, a reflection on who was eating there that night.  I feel compelled to write this because it was an incredibly uncomfortable experience for me and my dining partner, and the entire restaurant, because of an UGLY ANGRY FATHER.  This father, dining with his 2 young below 5 age children and his wife, verbally got into an altercation with an old man dining solo.  It was ugly and awful and the Father took things waaayyyy farther than necessary.  The Father was insulting and cruel to the old man.  To the old man's credit, he did not spit the vitriol back.  

I wish the restaurant had asked the Father and his family to leave.  Can you imagine, if that father is like that (angry, without control, verbally abusive) in PUBLIC with his family in tow, imagine what he is like behind closed doors!  His poor wife.   And his rant effected the tone of the whole restaurant.  You could hear a pin drop.  

I will be back for more sushi, but I hope that father does not return.
author: Yelper H.

description:
A friend took me here for dinner on a visit to San Fran.
The sushi was excellent and while I admit the service wasn't excellent, it didn't deter from the experience.

Definitely a must-visit restaurant on any visit to San Fran.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Heard rumor  that Hiromi left because the supposedly the Mama-san co-owner was too moody and Hiromi-san was going to try to start something else with a partner.
******
2006-One of the few sushi bars where Hiromi, Japanese WOMAN sushi chef was making it raw. Popped in after the Clay for a quickee and was only ok, but practically next door to the Clay!!!
author: miriam b.

description:
Mostly, I had a craving for the basic teriyaki steak and tempura which I ordered as a combo. The steak was pleasantly rare and tender (so often not the case). The tempura was decent enough, but I always look for something extra; a different vegetable to set it apart from others.

The nigiri sushi, on the other hand, was exquisite. Kevin and I ordered a variety of uni, toro, hamachi, shiro maguro, and ama-ebi were extremely fresh and tender. The service was fantastic and (after a stressful week travelling with my boss), the large selection of sake was well-appreciated. I believe we tried five or six different styles and enjoyed each one of them (realizing I need to start investigating sakes more thoroughly).
author: Carolyn T.

description:
For starters, their services is not the best.  There was one time where I called in the order, and they told me to show up in 15 minutes.  I went there 20 minutes later and they didn't even place my order in the kitchen!  I waited another 20 minutes!

The food is not bad...but overpriced.  I know it's at Pacific Heights, but still.  Who charges more than 10 dollars for veggie udon???
author: Jessica T.

description: If you like Japanese bento boxes. Come here. If you like the chicken teriyaki / tempura / california roll combination dinners with a miso soup and salad. Come here. If you like rolls with sauce. Come here. This is not  the authentic kind of restaurant you go to if you are craving fresh, melt in your mouth sashimi. But it's a taste of something different from many cafes and American restaurants in Pac Heights.
author: Alex H.

description:
Came here for Japanese food this past weekend and was a little disappointed. I ordered the Chirashi which was very good, the fish was fresh and a pretty good portion for $20. Where I felt was lacking was in the chicken and beef teriyaki that my friends ordered. The chicken tasted a little bit funny, not sure what the taste was but all of us at the table agreed. Service is friendly and the atmosphere is nice but I just couldn't get over the funny tasting chicken teriyaki.

I would say come here to order their specialty rolls and sushi, but stay away from the beef and chicken teriyaki.
author: Matt K.

description: I have been going to this restaurant for years, but never sat at the counter. It has always been pretty good. But last week came at 8:45pm with my daughter from NYC and found it to be awful. Service "We close in a few minutes.". Grilled unagi was cold. Delivered the wrong size order. Soooo disappointing. Is there new help behind the counter?
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
Very yummy but very expensive. 

My boyfriend and I are both hapa and as such we tend to be a bit picky about our Japanese food.  We both love this place.  But agree it's perhaps a little overpriced for what you get.  Then again, not many Japanese restaurants are actually owned and operated by Japanese people these days.  This one is, and it's food reflects that authenticity.  I don't mind paying more for good food.

I recommend sitting at the sushi bar which is at the back of the restaurant.  You might as well get the full show.  A little miso, a little iron chef ... all in all a good night.

FOR CHEAP BUT GOOD JAPANESE FOOD go to Kitaro on Geary.  It's a little further out there, but you can be stuffed for about half the price.
author: Mariko H.

description:
we would a famous sushi restaurant and we found it Here
nice family ambiance
author: jregnier

description: The fog decides not to back off and the misty wind is blowing up and down the streets of Pacific Heights.  A trip to Tenichi for a steaming iron pot of beef udon is just the thing to dispel that chill you to the bones feel on a summer day!  Really hungry and need something to fill that void in your belly?  They have great Donburi dishes and lunch combos for the heartier appetites. They also have a very reasonably-priced lunch special bento box daily and a decent selection of sushi.  I've been eating at Tenichi for more than 25 years and it never disappoints. Prices are a little higher than what you would find in Japantown for the most part, but probably in keeping with the higher rent they surely pay.
author: Eve C.

description: We go here for the udon and yosenabe more than the sushi.  It's always welcome on a cold winter's night.
author: David H.

description: Freshness you can taste! A little on the pricier side, but you know you are getting some quality food.  Service was great and the people are so friendly.
author: Nita K.

description:
homestyle japanese food is good, sushi is very sub par in comparison.

Order lots of yummy japanese food here; mushroom soup was fun and had lots of nice veggies, the hamachi kama was great too.

- dont order sushi. you will be sad - mine came out rolled lumpy and rather amature in construction - salmon wasnt rolled in smooth union- it was a couple piece lumped togeather. UGH
author: Haoming C.

description: This place isnt the best sushi ever, but it isnt the worst either.  The staff is friendly and it has a certain old school japanese, 80's furniture kinda feel to it.  It's a bit on the high end for pricing for sushi that isnt amazing, but the staff is friendly at least and there isnt usually a long wait.
author: christopher h.

description: I love going to this sushi restaurant for, believe it or not, vegan selections such as various types of veggie rolls, noodle soups and a super sizzling veggie plate. The atmosphere is very casual and the service is friendly. Recommended.
author: Bert C.

description: I don't know why I haven't written a review about this place yet but I remembered to do it ASAP when I ate there last night. ok hands down this place has THE BEST CHICKEN KARAAGE in SF!! I mean its crispy, flavorful, with a hint of teriyaki sauce...u can get it boneless or with bones. it is divine! and I love their NABEMONO Beef soup!! it is soooo good...seriously $16 for a huge bowl of that soup is totally worth it! it has lots of vegetables, noodles thick n thin, mushrooms, slices of onions and thin slices of beef....n that broth is out of this world! seriously I could eat the whole thing myself! well not in one sitting of course but yes! damn it! I could eat the WHOLE thing by myself! hahhahahha...ohh by the way try their cold noodle salad n u probably will not wanna eat the regular typical salad after that =)
author: Rika K.

description: I've been coming here since the early 80's, and have ordered the same entree almost every time.  they have the best, and I've yet to find anyone else who makes it like them.  I can count on one hand the number of times I've ordered something different.  Whether lunch or dinner, I order this one item.  What this one mouth watering item that I just love and have to come only here to get it? Of course it's their Chicken Kara-Age.  With my not liking sea food, their sushi bar (while it looks great) does not do anything for me, but their Chicken Kara-Age is to die for.
author: Rico K.

description: I must say, the sushi here is phenomenal!  Love the house smoked salmon, Fillmore roll, hamachi all very very good.  Nice atmosphere, actually possible to hold a conversation.  Happy hour ($2 draft beer).  Service is very good, the sushi guys are very user friendly!
author: Glenn S.

description: Went to the sushi bar.  the staffs are all friendly and quick.  I get to know chef Nobu and Ken and they're really down to earth and nice.  Ok, the food might be on the pricy side, but I'd say the ingredients are pretty decent.  I'd say a solid two pairs!
author: Francisco S.

description: Ten ichi's is consistently good when I eat there. Although this wouldn't be my first choice for sushi, there sushi is quite tasty and fresh. I really enjoy the eggplant tofu dish. It is very delicious, with just a enough spice and not too salty like some Asian restaurants. They have a good selection of vegetarian dishes which I like being a former vegetarian.
author: christina C.

description: I've been here a couple of times and I've definitely experienced better.  I come here out of laziness...I need rice (must have rice) or am craving sushi and am too lazy to walk further down to Japantown.  I must say, though, I just had dinner with a friend here who lived in the area (again, too lazy to walk to Japantown) and it was packed so they do have a following.
author: Abby N.

description: They've got to step up their game here.  You're paying through the nose for Pacific Heights location.  Please, Ten-ichi, become the sushi restaurant Fillmore Street so desperately needs (think Elephant or Okoze in Russian Hill).  The sushi rolls have very little fish actually in them which is so annoying given the price - they're all rice and seaweed wrap ... unlike any other place I've gone to in the area (Godzilla, Tataki, etc).  The nigiri comes slathered with a slimy wasabi on top of it - hate it.  I couldn't get over how high my bill was on my last two visits given the lack of fish in the rolls (I tried a traditional roll AND a hand-roll because I was stunned by the lack of fish in the first roll I ordered).  I almost sent the rolls back but I never send food back because it feels so weird.  Looking back, I really wish I had because I feel taken advantage of.  Instead this review will be my feedback.  Ten-ichi, you have the BEST Pacific Heights location and the cutest, most charming exterior AND interior (now that the carpet is gone).  Make the food better, c'mon once and for all!!!
author: Christin A.

description: Very disappointing. After all the decent reviews and a high rec from a good friend, I was psyched to go to Ten-Ichi up in Pac Heights. The place is nice-enough looking, though a bit outdated and complete with unexceptional service. I ordered Nabeyaki, which was tasty, but I've had far better udon noodles in SF (think Mifune). The salad that came w/ was wilted and seemed to have been prepared hours before. A friend said her seaweed salad was sub-par, while the edamame was cold and unsalted. Granted I didn't eat any sushi when I went (which seems to be what everyone's raving about in their reviews), I don't think I'll be heading back.
author: Brittany L.

description: This place is great for two reasons. 1) It is 30 year old family owned business and they make everyone feel like they are family too. 2) because they have been around for 30 years, they have an excellent rapport with the distributors. FYI everyone buys their product (fish) from the same distributor and customers who have the highest seniority get first dibs on the product. Last night I had a piece of Toro that was so fatted up, I felt like I had eaten a piece of bacon ( I love bacon). The Hamachi was spectacular and clearly the freshest I'd ever seen. It filled me up so quickly I didn't have enough room for their oh-so delicious rolls. If you want the higest quality sushi - which is very hard to get - this is the place.
author: Andrea C.

description: i really appreciate that they have several vegetarian options as this is rarely the case in Japanese restaurants. Service is attentive and the food is quite good.
author: JaM W.

description:
This is our go-to sushi place in the neighborhood.  The sushi is consistently good as is the other food, and the owners and sushi chefs are all very nice.   

-decent selection of fish and good fresh wasabi.
-sushi-style fish tacos are really good.
-Super Caliente roll if you like it hot.
-better to sit at the bar.
-beef negimaki is very good.
-mushroom soup is excellent.

They have a big TV behind the bar, so it's good for gamenight.
author: Billy B.

description: Excellent sashimi. Yummy and fresh. Enjoyable local dining experience. Cozy environment, reasonable prices, very pleasant service. Good sake selection. What more could you want? :)
author: Royce L.

description: The sushi and the service are at the very least adequate.   I am happy to have somewhere to get my tofu and sapporro.  Oh, and sake too!  I would not go out of my way to get here, but post-yoga it'll do.
author: Amme P.

description: The experience at Ten-Ichi is a combination of good Japanese food, very tasteful decor, and a sense of timelessness.  You can get cheaper sushi at KiKi's, and if you are on the way to somewhere else for the evening, this is not the place for you. I learned from my sister that when a finely prepared meal is served to you, that you should look at it carefully and with full attention, for that is what is deserved by those beings who have provided for you.  Locals (myself included) return regularly for this quality experience on upper Fillmore.
author: Gordon J.

description: This is one of the best sushi joints I've been too.  They have great dragon rolls and crunchy rolls.  YUM YUM!!!
author: Vanessa A.

description:
so-so sushi, slightly soulless setting 

(excuse the unnecessary alliteration)

the nigiri special for $20 was reasonable value, and certainly filled me up, but was lacking a bit in shnazziness. the fish was fresh, but the rice was somehow not quite right. the california rolls were also decent, but nothing to make your mouth water.

the tables were covered in one of those see-through glass protective plates that are popular in diners across the land to shield the tablecloth from unsightly stains, cheapening the whole experience and making me eat even more messily than i usually do just because i didn't need to worry about making a mess. and a mess i made.

all in all, decent, would go again if i happened to be in the area but not somewhere i'd actively seek out.
author: Niko V.

description: Waited for about 4 minutes at the entrance and didn't even get an acknowledgment - it was not chaotically busy and there were waitresses passing by. The sushi was good but not phenomenal. The miso soup was excellent but the yakitori was overcooked and too tough for chicken. I came with friends who preferred the non-nigiri rolls - and Crunchy was our favorite - nice texture and obviously crunchy, but in a subtle way. Again, though the waitresses were nice, the wait for getting a table, ordering, and getting our check was grating. Also, the decor was unbalanced and random- was it western art juxtaposing the "east?"
author: Audrey L.

description: Excellent sushi with a large and varied menu which includes alot more than just raw fish, including a whole section of veggie and extra-healthy foods. They also have a pretty good sake selection. A great place for a date since it's also quiet, and the service is very good too.
author: Steven G.

description: This place always serves up very good Japanese food.  The service can be a bit spotty at times---I've had to ask someone to take our order or ask for the check.  The wait staff is not always very friendly; perhaps they're just there to earn a paycheck, who knows. BUT, the food is worth going.  They've raised the prices kind of a lot (I've been going there for many, many years) which annoys me.  The biggest  no-no here is take-out.  NEVER leave without checking your order first!!!!  I'm serious.  They get it wrong 8 out of 10 times...seriously.  It's so bad we really try not to do take-out, but sometimes we don't have a choice.  They get a little snitty when you stand there checking your order and never say they're sorry when you point out their mistake(s).  And, they make you wait without even offering you tea or anything while they fix their error(s).
author: Lisa D.

description:
For what it is, I like it.  Food is good, the sushi was fresh and very good, portions on the cooked dishes were great.

Bear in mind, this is a family-type restaurant.  It's not a gastro-snob haven.  It's friendly, easy-going and has a TV in the back so if it's the end of a miserably long day dealing with infantile corporate jackasses and all you want is some good food, chill atmosphere, and mindless distraction (e.g. ANYTHING on TV for the most part), this is your place...
author: john r.

description: I have been going to this neighborhood sushi restaurant for over 10 years, and I've NEVER had a bad experience..the sushi is wonderful (sitting at the bar is the best), and is always fresh and delicious.  The service is also always excellent - it has a warm, friendly atmosphere.  They've been in business almost 30 years and I hope to see them for another 30.
author: Ingrid E.

description: A decent spot for sushi and japanese food. Sushi was ok, but not overwhelmingly great.  Prices are okay, service was nice. Maguro, caterpillar and california rolls were good; miso is always just a lovely bowl of yummyness.  Chicken karage was mostly fried batter with very little chicken.  Ahh... but the saporo on draught comes in chilled beer mugs.  Loved that!
author: Danielle R.

description:
friday night.

special app tuna carpaccio was repulsive. maybe they were just trying to get rid of some old, poor cut of fish by drowning it in vinegar. too bad, didn't work, still stinky and chewy.

udon flavors were good, but noodles were a little too cooked for my taste.

service was good. prices were inflated.
author: Dana D.

description:
I was surprised with the reviews, because this is my favorite place for sushi.  This is because I can get my sushi spicy, yum!

I love spicy foods, so the Super Caliente Roll (eel and jalapeno tempura with red spicy sauce) is my "usual."  Also, order the Hotate Ngiri "spicy," the chef adds this spicy creamy sauce, oh so good.  Among my other favorites:  Nuclear roll (spicy california roll), ultimate roll, crunchy roll.  The saba ngiri and unagi ngiri is always fresh and oh so wonderful.  The last time I went, we sat at the sushi bar and that was a lot of fun!  Ask the chef about the specials and tell him about what you like (yes, you guessed it, I like it spicy!) and he will aim to please!  

Other items on the menu are pretty good, too.  My husband loves the ton katsu, it's his usual.  When I was pregnant, I would crave the udon (vegetable or seafood are my favorite!).  

I have always had a good experience here, and I love that the hostess always honors my daughter's request to "sit near the fish."  I wish there was a similar place in the east bay where I live.
author: Aileen D.

description:
stopped in for some quick bites since we had a movie to catch within the half hour at the clay theatre next door. 

since we only ordered rolls, i can't really speak to the rest of their menu and how well a "thorough" meal would pan out. in terms of ambiance, it's nothing incredibly special, but it's intimate, quiet, nice. 

the rolls were overall very satisfying, textural, and tasty. best of all, they weren't drowned in cloying sticky sauce and sesame seeds. you could actually taste the flavors of each individual ingredient. 

the breakdown:

tekka maki - good, but the maguro was lacking that fresh bite. also, i like my tekka maki with slivers of crisp cucumber. 

the ultimate roll - awesome. entertained all the taste buds.

the clay roll - like the california roll, but with some embellishments. real crab. good.

the nuclear roll - also very nice. spicy. the tobiko was loaded on, but not annoyingly so.
author: jennifer y.

description:
nothing compares to my favorite Sanraku for my sushi cravings but if need be Ten-ichi is alright.   

We call this place the roast beef bonito because that's what it tastes like. it's all very odd.
author: Ariana M.

description: Walking distance from my place, Ten-Ichi is the perfect, impromptu dinner spot.  We ordered 2 seaweed salads, 3 rolls, and 4 glasses of wine.  The bill was $40 each, quite reasonable.  Everything was delicious.  The service was very friendly and the atmosphere was warm.  Definitely a neighborhood favorite.
author: Patty V.

description: I have been there a couple of times. Last time I went to, I ordered sushis and some rolles. so fresh! Hamachi was really good. The service was good too. The food was late and they gave us match icecream for a complement...
author: jin k.

description: Excellent selection of very fresh fish for nigiri sushi.  Even on the dreaded Monday sushi (supposedly fish won't be fresh...) the fish WAS fresh and tasty.  Toro, Yellow Tail, Uni (Sea Urchin), Kampachi... all excellent quality and portion size.  Several interesting rolls were good too.  Servers were also very friendly and helpful with our questions (Date preferred a table to the bar...).  New in town and first sushi here, but as a longtime aficionado, was very impressed and will return.  Maybe there is better sushi in town , but will be surprised if there is... It can't get much better!
author: Mark M.

description: My favorite sushi place in town.  Try the mochi ice-cream for dessert.
author: Monika M.

description: Best sushi joint on Fillmore (side note: why is all the food on Fillmore generally mediocre? one of SF's great mysteries).  Very fresh fish, generous servings.  The maguro is melt-in-your-mouth and recently they've had spectacular white tuna.  The starters are quite good as well, and the prices are really reasonable.  I'm not really a roll guy but my friends have always enjoyed them there.  And unlike most restaurants in San Francisco, this place has been there for a generation and people keep coming back.  Service can be a bit slow.
author: Geoff K.

description: J-town is 8 blocks away and you are better off walking 8 blocks than eating here.  But since I am fat and can't walk that far this place serves decent food at an expensive price.  Welcome to Pac Heights!
author: Fatty A.

description: Wanted to try a new sushi place so we gave Ten-ichi a try.  The decor was traditional Japanese tawdry but the dishes looked great.  After searching for an extensive sushi menu and not coming up with anything, I settled on the tuna carpaccio and the bf had the beef steak teriyaki .  After we ordered, we found the sushi on one of the little stand-up menus on the table, but I was happy and hoping for good things with the tuna.  Boy, was I right!  Large chunks of fresh & melt-in-your-mouth tuna covered in a uber-yummy garlic & cilantro sauce... I was in heaven.  The beef steak came out on a sizzling platter, tender & in a great teriyaki sauce.  I have to say I was pleasantly surprised by this little Fillmore find.
author: Tara G.

description: I think this place ranks among the average-good sushi places, but isn't one that I would necessarily drive out of my way to go to.  The fish was a little dry, but beautifully presented, and quick.  The space itself is nice for either a date or a family, and we didn't have to wait long to be seated.  Prices are a little bit on the more-expensive side (still prefer my Red Box).
author: Mark D.

description: The food is cheap and one of the better places on Filmore.  The service is quite slow however.  I usually just get the lunch special.  Recommend this place only if you work are the area.  I would not go out of my way to go eat here.
author: Christopher D.

description: This is one of the many underwhelming restaurants on upper Fillmore.  I have eaten here twice, both times I was not at all impressed with the service, the food, the ambiance.  Why did I keep coming back? Because there is no good sushi on Fillmore near my house and some times I just don't want to travel too far for some fish.  The prices are average, as is the food.
author: Nilu r.

description: FRRRESH!! New favorite place. It's a very zen experience. And they have the good brand of green tea ice cream...not to mention KILLER uni with quail egg.
author: Jennifer B.

description: 5 stars because the sushi is that good.  I've eaten here many times in the past few months and each time is just as good as the first time (isn't that like some 80's Sade lyric in reverse?).  Tuna tataki, the Ultimate Roll, and everything else is sooooooo good you'll disregard the occasionally blase service.
author: Tracy E.

description: Really good sushi! I was totally impressed by this place, it totally under promises and over delivers. Was here last night, I liked the vibe as soon as I walked in which was very chilled out and not hip at all. Ordered some sashimi and sushi, my fave was the crunch roll, I would highly recommend this one. The Jurassic was just about ok, but the dragon roll redeemed itself as well. I would definitely go back and try their terriayaki which looked pretty extensive on the menu.
author: Pooja S.

description: just like many of the other places in the neighborhood, Ten-Ichi is a good casual restaurant.  Service is prompt and friendly, food is reasonably priced and tasty.  Last night the real stand out was the tuna sashimi - excellent cuts of fish, very fresh and nicely presented.  The yellowtail was only ok.  Excellent salad and tea.  Overall a comfortable easy place and I'd definitely go back.
author: J P.

description: So, the decor is unimpressive but since I stroll by here almost every day on my way home, I one day decided to give it a try....and boy was I surprised.  This place has really good sushi and authentic Japanese food (call me a snob but my mom is Japanese so I feel like I have the right to judge).   It is on the pricey side but I don't think I've ordered anything that I disliked.  The chicken karage appetizer is VERY delicious as well are the rolls (my favorite is the shrimp tempura roll...whatever they call it).  One of my favorite restaurants on Fillmore!
author: Lisa L.

description: Ok food , good portions! Very consistent in taste. I go once a month. Service is pretty good. They don't bug you. If you want a family style type of place. Lots of screaming kids and tight seating.  Go early to avoid the kids.The weekends get pretty busy! A lot of regulars! They raised their prices by $3-6 per entree. I just lower the rating, the price is too expensive for what you get now!
author: Alison W.

description: One of the worst dining experiences i have had in 3 years in the city.  Servers brought food to the wrong table at 2 different times.  The tofu salad still had the markings from the plastic container it came from and was just a block on a plate covered in lettuce.  Sushi was small and overpriced.  Lacked any authenticity, originality, or care.  overpriced for poor service, outdated decor, really poor cuisine.
author: Christian W.

description: I love this place. I got hooked when I lived in SF. Now I live down in the south bay, but I drive up to SF just for Ten Ichi. The salmon is always amazing. And they have the most interesting rolls I've found anywhere. Always something new to try. And if I've tried everything, they'll make something up. Honestly, they'll probably hate me for saying this, but the made up ones are almost always the best. Maybe it's knowing you might never get this small bit of heaven again (since they don't write down what they're doing and don't have a name for it) that makes you savor it a bit more, but really, they are just criminally good. Now I'm craving.
author: Rachel W.

description: Ten-Ichi is our "go to" sushi place in the neighborhood.  Very friendly staff.  I especially like that their menu is fairly large and varied, and that their food is fresh.  Most things that I have had on the menu are very good.  Stand-out are their home-smoked salmon, the variety in their chirashi, and the green bean and chicken saute.
author: J M.

description: This place has a great menu with an impressive amount of vegetarian options.  That was really what made us try it, in spite of the fact a friend said she hated it!  The fish was super fresh and hands down, it was the best salmon I have in since moving to San Francisco almost a year ago.  Three of us shared about 4 rolls and 3 orders of nigiri while my vegetarian girlfriend had a delicious sake and soy sauce flavored tofu and vegetable plate.  The service was fast and friendly and the bill was only $100 (including two bottles of sake) for four people total.  I would defnitely go there again and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it.
author: J L.

description: I was really hungry, so I basically inhaled my food instead of tasting it.  My stomach is happy, though my tastebuds have already forgotten.
author: Joanna S.

description: Wow. what a rip-off. I was literally starving after dropping $27 on a tartar salad appetizer and a salmon roll. With 20 other options in a mile radius, I am not coming back.
author: Nicole S.

description: Came here recently with a friend and we had a lot of gossiping and catching up to do, the servers totally left us alone to talk (but almost too much since we had to flag them down to let them know that we wanted to order already), but service was pretty good.  I wasn't very hungry so i ordered one of my favorite appetizer dishes, the tempura.  It came piping hot, crispy and very delicious! The sauce i think even had bits of mashed up ginger.  We shared a dish of sashimi, a bit pricey for the 3 thin slices of the hamachi and 3 square pieces of the tuna, but the sashimi itself was delicious. Very good quality fish.   We also ordered a philadelphia roll, i don't usually like cream cheese in my rolls, but this was pretty tasty. not too much.
author: Lulu C.

description: I have been meaning to try this place for about a year now, since I walk past it everyday.  Last night was my lucky night!  I went for take out and got the crunchy roll (which is very good but the best crunchy roll that I had was from some kosher sushi place down in LA).  I also got a couple orders of nigiri.  The fish was fresh and even though I got take out I was given some tea to sip on while they were preparing my order.  I would definitely come back because they had a wide variety of Japanese food that I wanted to come back and try!
author: Lorraine Y.

description: Hit up the sushi bar. Rolls not on the menu are on the chalkboard, and are worth it.
author: Scott F.

description: This is the only sushi in the city I will eat. Fish still quivering its so fresh, awesome cold noodle salad, and top notch service (with little hot towels on arrival). The hamachi temptation roll is awesome but not on the menu you have to ask for it.
author: Michael R.

description: Great Pac Heights sushi bar that serves up fresh fish at affordable prices.  We sat at the sushi bar and told John to give us the Chef's Special--whatever he felt was the best.  That he did.  We happily devoured six orders of sushi and one roll.  I was a bit disappointed that they don't serve Asahi Black.  Other than that, I will be back.
author: Andrew F.

description: I have been going to this restaurant since the late 80's, and just today I noticed the sign out front said open for thirty years. What keeps places like this open so long is the friendly atmosphere and definitely the good food.  One of my all time favorites is the Chicken Kara-age.  Good luck towards another 30 years.
author: C J.

description: The best Chicken Karaage anywhere!: Ten-ichi is a fillmore district neighborhood japanese restaurant that offer a wide variety of dishes. Their sushi is very fresh and made "american syle" meaning lots of creative maki's and different sauces. All of their food is consistent and ample in portions. The one dish that stands out above all the rest is their Chicken Karaage. Every Japanese restaurant I've been to from as far south in San Jose to San Francisco, Ten-ichi's Karaage stands out above all the rest. Just try it! I promise you'll agree! Overall, the quality of the food is excellent, the service very good, and the ambiance very comfortable. The Fillmore is lucky to have this establishment in the neighborhood.
author: M V.

description:
Maybe we were there on an off night, or maybe you have to order the cooked food, but we found this place to be mediocre at best.  We ordered all sushi--tuna (maguro) , yellowtail (hamachi), salmon (sake), monkfish liver (?), and mackerel (saba)--and only the mackerel was decent.  The rest was barely okay.  It was either bad cuts, or unskilled selection by the chef.  I think the rice had too much sugar, too, which drowns out the flavor and consistency of the fish.
When we try out a new sushi place, we generally order a round, and then order another round of what was good.  We didn't order another round.  It was that bad.  We left hungry and picked up something small at Thai Stick.
The service was fine.  The atmosphere was okay.  Overall, I would say there are much better places in the area.
author: Jason T.

description:
I love this place and go back every time I have a chance.
